title: Queen's small gestures that gave away her true feelings during speech
text:

The Queen's relationship with No10, and particularly Boris Johnson, is reportedly at rock bottom.

The 93-year-old monarch is said to have asked for a copy of the Queen's Speech a week in advance to ensure there was no slips up during her reading today.

Lat month judges ruled that Boris Johnson lied to the Queen over his reasons for proroguing parliament and that the suspension of parliament was unlawful.

And body language expert Judi James has studied the reading of the Queen's Speech in the House of Lords earlier today.

(Image: WPA Pool)

(Image: Getty Images)

What body language Judi James said...

The Queen is one of the best professional body language maskers in public life, able to disguise her genuine emotions in public to present a regal and often neutral front.

This, along with her age, can make reliable readings less accurate than they are with most of those politicians watching her speech today.

Overall she appeared stronger than she did during her previous two speeches though, when her voice sounded frail and higher in pitch.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: Leon Neal)

Her lower tone here has more authority, as do the moments when she glances up from her script to fix her ministers with what looks like a meaningful stare.

Her speech begins with some facial gestures that in anyone but the Queen might look cynical.

As she talks about Brexit she seems to raise one eyebrow and there is a small pulling in of her lips when she mentions the 31st October.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: PA)

She also raises both brows and performs a small head-wobble at the end of the Brexit section.

At the end of her speech she looks across at her ministers again.

She stops, pulls in her lips and looks down and to one side in a pose that looks sadly reflective.
description: Relationships between the Queen and Number 10 are 'at rock bottom' - but did the monarch's body language give anything away?
